name: Six Thinking Hats
description: Structured brainstorming method that encourages parallel thinking by examining issues from six different perspectives. Excellent for comprehensive decision-making and creative problem-solving.

structure.name: White Hat (Facts)
structure.description: Focus on available data, facts, and information. What do we know? What do we need to know?

structure.name: Red Hat (Emotions)
structure.description: Express feelings, intuition, and emotional reactions without justification

structure.name: Black Hat (Risks)
structure.description: Identify potential problems, risks, and negative consequences. Exercise caution

structure.name: Yellow Hat (Benefits)
structure.description: Focus on positives, benefits, and optimistic outcomes. Identify opportunities

structure.name: Green Hat (Creativity)
structure.description: Explore alternatives, generate new ideas, and consider innovative solutions

structure.name: Blue Hat (Process)
structure.description: Manage the thinking process, summarize findings, and plan next steps

prompts: WHITE HAT: What are the facts? What information do we have? What do we need to know?
RED HAT: How do I feel about this? What's my gut reaction? What emotions come up?
BLACK HAT: What could go wrong? What are the risks and potential problems? What are the weaknesses?
YELLOW HAT: What are the benefits? What are the opportunities? What's the best-case scenario?
GREEN HAT: What new approaches could we try? What alternatives exist? How else could we solve this?
BLUE HAT: What have we learned so far? What's our next step? How should we proceed?
when_to_use: When teams need to consider all perspectives before making decisions
When brainstorming needs structure and direction
When analyzing complex situations with multiple stakeholders
When conflict arises from different viewpoints
When creative thinking needs to be combined with analytical rigor
When facilitating group discussions and workshops
when_not_to_use: When quick, spontaneous decisions are needed
When working alone on simple problems
When time is extremely limited (minimum 30 minutes needed)
When the group is not receptive to structured thinking

examples.title: Product Feature Decision
examples.description: Team used Six Hats to decide on adding AI features. White: market data, Red: excitement about innovation, Black: implementation risks, Yellow: competitive advantage, Green: alternative approaches, Blue: action plan.

examples.title: Organizational Change
examples.description: Company restructuring analysis. White: financial data, Red: employee concerns, Black: disruption risks, Yellow: efficiency gains, Green: alternative structures, Blue: implementation timeline.

validation_status.validation_notes: Widely adopted creative thinking and decision-making framework
